posts.name: zoe
posts.cooked:
Hello,

Upon deploying code to a RoboRIO 2—with indication of “BUILD SUCCESSFUL”—the DS app shows “No Robot Code” and the logs indicate that the code has not finished initialization. Sometimes (about 75% no robot code / 25% robot code green) deploying code will be successful. A picture of the DS logs upon fail and upon success are both attached (upon fail, the roboRIO INFO line will print indefinitely).

Upon success: img_20250312_190434 1002×1332 349 KB

img_20250312_190434 1002×1332 349 KB

img_20250312_190434 1002×1332 349 KB

Upon fail: img_20250312_190543 1002×1332 305 KB

img_20250312_190543 1002×1332 305 KB

img_20250312_190543 1002×1332 305 KB

We have SSHed into the roboRIO when no robot code was reported—the java process running the code was running.

When powercycling the robot and/or restarting the robot code, VERY RARELY we’ve gotten it to display green for robot code, when starting with no robot code, but the robot behavior corresponds to old code not from most recent deploy. Doing the same thing, COMMONLY it will display no robot code when starting with green for robot code.

We have tried:

Closing and reopening DS app

Trying old code / vendor library versions that previously worked (the issue persists)

Reimaging the microSD card

Trying a brand new SD card

Code can be found here: GitHub - missfits/Robot-Code-2025 at zoe/fix-no-robot-code-issue

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Since the error message mentions rust, I’m guessing it has something to do with libgrapple.

posts.name: zoe
posts.cooked:
We see that message normally, before we had this issue.

Also, the rust message only happens upon success and not upon fail.

posts.name: Steven Carmain
posts.cooked:
I know my code takes like 15 seconds to initialize in Simulation, and about as long on a robot.  From observation, it seemed like Phoenix motor init is slow with YAGSL , and we do have grapple stuff too.  I haven’t isolated it past that.  Neo simulation is much faster in YAGSL .

(I don’t know if it’s also because we have a CANivore, and simulation is trying to find the robot over usb because you can pc use motors over the CANivore in simulation)

posts.name: zoe
posts.cooked:
“No Robot Code” will show indefinitely upon fail. See attached image, which has 2 minutes worth of logs.

PXL_20250313_013644755.MP 1002×1332 392 KB

PXL_20250313_013644755.MP 1002×1332 392 KB

PXL_20250313_013644755.MP 1002×1332 392 KB

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
@Jaci Just in case it is a libgrapple error, but that doesn’t seem most likely to me right now.

Edit: nvm, though understanding that rust message would be nice

posts.name: zoe
posts.cooked: Found the source of the issue. We doubled the length of our LEDs in code (and accidentally ran setLength() twice on our AddressableLEDs), which was (likely) taking a LOT to run during initialization of our LEDSubsystem. Thanks everyone for their help!

data.title: No Robot Code due to presumed lockup during initialization
data.fancy_title: No Robot Code due to presumed lockup during initialization

accepted_answer.excerpt:
Found the source of the issue. We doubled the length of our LEDs in code (and accidentally ran setLength() twice on our AddressableLEDs), which was (likely) taking a LOT to run during initialization of our LEDSubsystem. 
Thanks everyone for their help!
